attributes.title: When gender incongruency is not a problem: Evidence from artificial language learning
attributes.description: Research Data and Materials for an article

summary.value: This repository contains research data and materials to run the experiment described in the article "When Gender Incongruency is not a Problem: Evidence from Artificial Language Learning": stimuli, experimental code, raw data and analysis.

registration_responses.summary: This repository contains research data and materials to run the experiment described in the article "When Gender Incongruency is not a Problem: Evidence from Artificial Language Learning": stimuli, experimental code, raw data and analysis.

attributes.title: GoodReports
attributes.description: Developing and testing the effectiveness of an online tool to help health researchers find and use reporting guidelines to improve the completeness of reporting
attributes.withdrawal_justification: I registered the project not the randomized trial

attributes.title: Do personality traits predict noise sensitivity and speech-in-noise comprehension?
attributes.description: The originally pre-registered experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj) has been conducted and the data have been analysed. In order to verify the robustness of the results, we here pre-register the recording of a second, independent sample of participants in the same online-experiment (including two additional questionnaires; see below for details).

q1.value: Malte Wöstmann, Jonas Obleser, Jens Kreitewolf, Julia Erb

q2.value:
Our initial hypotheses for this study (OSF pre-registration, September 19, 2019; https://osf.io/pvnwj) still apply, with the following exceptions (see below).

In agreement with our initial hypotheses, we found that higher neuroticism is related to increased levels of noise sensitivity, decreased experienced speech comprehension in the SSQ questionnaire, and lower levels of acceptable background noise in the ANL test. Also in line with our initial hypotheses, weaker associations in the opposite direction were found for extraversion.

Opposite to what we had originally hypothesised, we found that performance in the Digit Triplet Test (DTT; which objectively quantifies speech comprehension accuracy in background noise) increased with higher levels of neuroticism.

In order to test whether these results are reliable and replicable, we here pre-register testing of an independent sample of participants in the same online study.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present experiment will be executed as an online experiment using the platform labvanced (www.labvanced.com). Questionnaires will be presented visually in a full screen browser window. Auditory stimuli will be delivered by the audio device attached to the computer of the participant, which can be loudspeakers or headphones.

q7.value:
The order of individual tests (Big 5; SSQ; Weinstein’s noise sensitivity scale; ANL test; DTT test) will be randomized across participants to exclude order effects. The Noise Exposure questionnaire, which was not included in testing of the first sample of participants, will always be placed in the end of the online experiment.

The participant sample will not be selected randomly but participants actively assign for the experiment online. The study sample will foreseeably be representative, since every German native speaking adult in Germany (18–80 years) with internet access can participate.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value:
The initially pre-registered experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj) has been conducted and we have analysed the data of N = 553 participants. 
Here, we pre-register an attempt to replicate the already obtained results in a second, independent sample of participants.

question.value:
Since this procedure of data collection worked well in the initially pre-registered experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj), we will use a very similar procedure in the present replication study:

The online platform used for the present study (Labvanced; www.labvanced.com) uses online-crowdsourcing via Amazon Mechanical Turk, Profilic, and Clickworker. This way, we will recruit an initial sub-sample of approximately N=400 participants. Participants should be German native speakers in the age range 18–80 years.

After checking the age distribution in the already collected sample, we will record another approximately N=100 participants. For this final sub-sample, we will restrict the age range for participation so that the achieved age distribution in the sample will be as broad (between 18-80 years) and as uniform as possible.

q11.value: The sample size in this replication attempt will be at least N=500 human participants.

q12.value: The rationale of the present experiment is to replicate the results of the initially pre-registered experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj), which has been conducted in a sample of > 500 participants (N = 553). Thus, to be able to reach same levels of statistical power, we will again require a sample size of at least 500 participants in the present replication attempt.

q13.value: We will stop data recording as soon as the sample size reaches N=500 participants who have completed the entire online experiment.

question.value:
In addition to manipulated variables described in the initially pre-registered experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj), we will here add two questionnaires to the experiment:

First, after finishing the DTT test, participants will provide answers to an adapted version of the NASA task load index, including 5 items.

Second, we will use a questionnaire (adopted from Liberman et al. 2012. PLOS ONE; DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0162726; Questionnaire 3, Part 1&2) to assess participants' Noise exposure, experienced loudness, and annoyance by different everyday sounds.

In addition to the variables measured in the initially pre-registered online study (https://osf.io/pvnwj), we will assess listening effort and noise exposure/annoyance in the following manner:

After participants have completed the DTT test, they will provide answers to 5 items, which have been adapted from the NASA task load index and translated to German. Participants will use a scale from 1 (very little) to 10 (very much) to answer the following items:
1) How high was your mental demand for this listening test?
2) How high do you estimate your performance in this listening test?
3) How much effort did you invest to reach your level of performance?
4) How high was your degree of frustration during the listening test?
5) How high was the amount of trials for which you gave up, since the listening test became too difficult?

Participants' noise exposure, experienced loudness, and annoyance by different everyday sounds will be assessed using a German version of the questionnaires used by Liberman et al. 2012. PLOS ONE

The statistical analysis will be carried out in two major steps.
First, we will use the same statistical models as pre-registered for the original experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj) and apply these to the data recorded in the present replication attempt. 
Second, we will use these statistical models on the combined data from the original study (https://osf.io/pvnwj) and the present replication attempt.

q18.value: In case of severe violations to the normality assumption of the general linear model (applies here to bivariate correlation as well as multiple regression), log or inverse transforms of the outcome variables will be considered.

q19.value: Alpha=0.05; two-tailed; A priori Power larger than 0.8

q20.value:
The same data exclusion criteria as for the original experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj) apply: 

Incomplete datasets of individual participants will be included in the analysis as long as the demographic information and at least one of the following tests is recorded: Big 5; SSQ; Weinstein’s noise sensitivity scale; ANL test; DTT test.

Questionnaires in the present study (Big 5; SSQ; Weinstein’s noise sensitivity scale; Noise Exposure; adapted version of the NASA task load index) include items that require the participant to choose a particular response (e.g., “choose the rightmost answer on this item”). In case a participant does not comply with these items for a given questionnaire, data of this questionnaire will be excluded.

Results of the DTT test will be excluded if the participant performs correct in less than 6 of 24 trials (i.e., less than 25 %). 

Results of the ANL test will be excluded in case the SNL (Soft Noise Level; measures as dB SNR) value is smaller than the LNL (Loud Noise Level; measures as dB SNR) value or in case the ANL (Acceptable Noise Level; measures as dB SNR) value is outside the range between SNL and LNL values.

q21.value:
The same handling of missing data will be used as for the original experiment (https://osf.io/pvnwj):

Incomplete datasets of individual participants will be included in the analysis as long as the demographic information and at least one of the following tests is recorded: Big 5; SSQ; Weinstein’s noise sensitivity scale; ANL test; DTT test.

q22.value:
Exploratory analyses will be carried out to explore the potentially mediating role of listening effort and noise exposure for the relation of neuroticism and performance in the DTT test. We consider it possible that the relationship of neuroticism and performance in the DTT test is (partially) mediated by listening effort and/or noise exposure. That is, listeners scoring higher on neuroticism might invest more effort in challenging listening situations, which eventually results in higher perceived task load but improved performance.
In a similar manner, we will explore a potentially mediating role of experienced noise loudness/annoyance in the relationship of personality (especially neutroticism) and tests of noise sensitivity and speech comprehension in noise.

q23.value:
Study type:
The ANL test and DTT are experiments: We vary the independent variable SNR and measure a listener’s acceptable noise level in the ANL test and the noise level corresponding to 50% correct performance in the DTT test. All answers to questionnaires are considered observational measures.

attributes.title: Moral values
attributes.description:
Moral Foundations Theory (MFT) purports to identify five essential "foundations" of human morality.  MFT also suggests that liberals have a narrower morality by attending to only the "individualizing foundations" (harm and fairness), contrasted to the broader morality of conservatives, who attend more to the "binding" foundations (authority, loyalty, and purity).  The present project suggests, instead, that MFT misses fundamental value tradeoffs made by liberals and conservatives by defining morality, or moral values, too narrowly.  To challenge MFT, I select from the broader framework of Schwartz Value Theory, abstracting four values (obedience, status, universalism, and self-direction) from the Schwartz value circumplex.  To enable a direct comparison with the five foundations of MFT, I “translate” these four values into the exact operational language of MFT (i.e., using scale items assessing moral relevancy and moral judgment).  In Study 1, multidimensional scaling of these nine moral constructs (5 foundations + 4 values; n=129) produced a moral circumplex consistent with SVT.  The pattern suggests MFT’s individualizing and binding foundations capture only two narrow slices of the broader moral circumplex.   Further, the predicted trade-offs emerge (e.g., obedience and universalism occupy opposing sides of the circumplex and correlate negatively).  Further, the broader model improves prediction of ideological commitments (e.g., low universalism and low self-direction improve prediction of economic conservatism).  

The Study 2 proposed here will extend Study 1 findings.  Specifically, I seek to develop a fifth SVT value to improve the prediction of conservatism, namely "security."  I also add a validated measure of social and economic conservatism to better compare predictive validity of the MFT and SVT models.  In general, I hope to replicate the basic multidimensional scaling outcome from Study 1 to demonstrate that MVT identifies only a subset of a broader set of moral concerns.  In addition, I hope to compare the ability of the two models to predict overall ideological orientation and position on specific political issues (e.g., abortion and gun control).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The design is correlational.

data.name: OFS, MDS, comparing MFT and SV4 predicting specific political issues.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: OFS, MDS, comparing MFT and SV4 predicting specific political issues.pdf

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Exclusion rules: An increasing percentage of mTurk participants have learned to correctly answer typical attention check items (e.g., instructions to select "strongly disagree for a particular item) and yet not provide adequate engagement with the survey.  I therefore use a multi-factorial approach to identify the least attentive respondents.  

Specifically, I will include participants who pass the initial instruction-reading check (Oppenheimer, Meyvis, & Davidenko, 2009), complete the survey, and do not fall into the least -attentive 15th percentile on two or more of five criteria:  a more positive correlation between a set of 11 paired antonyms (Meade & Craig, 2012), missed attention check items (i.e., questions regarding which item appeared on the previous page), overuse of any single Likert-scale value (on 1-7 scale), high standard deviation across all Likert-scale values, high average standard deviation across scales (on 1-7 scale; Marjanovic, Holden, Struthers, Cribbie, & Greenglass, 2015), and speed.  (All of these operations will be reflected in the SPSS code to ensure others can replicate the exclusions exactly).  

Note, as I'm still developing best practices for this, I still examine the response patterns closely and determine how well my exclusion criteria are working.  I may alter them slightly based on how they appear to perform.  If so, I will explain exactly how I do this and I will retain all obtained data in case someone later suggests an alternative standard for exclusion.

q11.value: I plan to collect data from 230 people.

q12.value: To be honest, I have no specific framework guiding this number other than experience.  I am more interested in the general pattern of relationships and am not worried about any particular relationship being significant.

q13.value: I will set the initial participant request in mTurk to be 1/3 larger than I ultimately desire (i.e., 306), expecting I will exclude about 1/3 of participants.  After applying the exclusion criteria, I will post another HIT if I am not at or close to 230, again using my 1/3 larger rule.

question.value:
n/a

I'm attaching a print-out of the Qualtrics protocol so people can see the exact items used.

The moral foundations are measured as specified for the MFQ (Graham et al., 2011).  My MV4 (last study) and the MV5 (this study) are designed to match the format of the MFQ.  Thus, in study 1, I wrote 6 moral relevancy items and 6 moral judgment items for each value (obedience, status, universalism, and self-direction).  I them select 3 of the former and 3 of the latter with the highest inter-item correlation values to comprise 6 item measures of each value, for 24 items total.  In study 2, I'm expanding the MV4 to the MV5 by adding a measure of security using the same procedure described above.  I will then use those five scales.  

The single issue political issue items were written by me in hopes of capturing different aspects of the SVT circumplex.  The self-report measures of conservatism are simply single item measures for assessing overall, social, and economic conservatism.  The scaled measures of social and economic conservatism used the SECS, with the gun issue dropped (Everett, 2013).  I am also pilot testing two issue item scales assessing attitudes towards sex ed (3 items) and female empowerment (5 items).
For all scales, simple means are computed.
see Hypothesis Testing attachment and SPSS code

q18.value: Schwartz requires his data to be centered, so I have built that process into the code.  However, as it is not logically clear to me whether I should then center the Moral Foundations scales, I plan on doing it both ways and presenting both sets of results.

registration_responses.q10.question:
Exclusion rules: An increasing percentage of mTurk participants have learned to correctly answer typical attention check items (e.g., instructions to select "strongly disagree for a particular item) and yet not provide adequate engagement with the survey.  I therefore use a multi-factorial approach to identify the least attentive respondents.  

Specifically, I will include participants who pass the initial instruction-reading check (Oppenheimer, Meyvis, & Davidenko, 2009), complete the survey, and do not fall into the least -attentive 15th percentile on two or more of five criteria:  a more positive correlation between a set of 11 paired antonyms (Meade & Craig, 2012), missed attention check items (i.e., questions regarding which item appeared on the previous page), overuse of any single Likert-scale value (on 1-7 scale), high standard deviation across all Likert-scale values, high average standard deviation across scales (on 1-7 scale; Marjanovic, Holden, Struthers, Cribbie, & Greenglass, 2015), and speed.  (All of these operations will be reflected in the SPSS code to ensure others can replicate the exclusions exactly).  

Note, as I'm still developing best practices for this, I still examine the response patterns closely and determine how well my exclusion criteria are working.  I may alter them slightly based on how they appear to perform.  If so, I will explain exactly how I do this and I will retain all obtained data in case someone later suggests an alternative standard for exclusion.

attributes.title: ACL Scoping Review
attributes.description: To review the evidence of the exercises selected in ACL prevention programs and identify any gaps existing in the literature.

q2.value: A scoping review of the exercises used in an ACL prevention program.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A scoping review

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: A scoping review of the exercises used in an ACL prevention programs. The exercises have been extracted but not analyzed as of 4/08/2020

question.value: NA

Will be analyzing exercises in 9 different categories.  Multi-Planar: 1. Saggittal, 2. Frontal, and 3. Transverse, 4. Bilateral Weight Bearing. 5. Single Limb Stance, 6. Z- Axis Rotation, 7. Eccentric Emphasis of the Hip ERs, 8. Top Down Hip Control, 9. Flight Phase w/ Landing

1.	Multiplanar
o	The exercise must include primary movement across two or more of the three cardinal planes. If an exercise was scored as multiplanar, then the two or three planes were also identified in the analysis.

2.	Sagittal Plane
o	The primary movement of the exercise occurred within the sagittal plane. Supine straight leg raise in supine is an example of isolated movement about the sagittal plane.

3.	Frontal Plane
o	The primary movement of the exercise occurred across the frontal plane. An example of an isolated exercise to the frontal plane would be a sidelying straight leg raise 

4.	Transverse Plane
o	The primary movement of the exercise occurred across the transverse plane. Exercises that are more difficult to categorize, such as the “clam” were put into transverse and frontal if the author reported it as utilizing two planes of motion. Seated external rotation is an isolated transverse plane exercise.

5.	Z-axis Rotation
o	The exercise needed to provide a force that would induce an internal rotation of the femur about the longitudinal z-axis of the body as illustrated in FIG. XX. The hip and knee must be in an extended position as if the body is in a weight bearing alignment. 
 
6.	Bilateral Weight Bearing
o	The primary movement of the exercise had both lower extremities contacting the ground in a long axis position where the hip was in a position of extension with the acetabulum over the femur in an upright bipedal position. Quadruped was not considered bilateral weight-bearing for this reason.

7.	Single Limb Stance
o	The exercise was performed on one lower extremity that was full weight bearing and contacting the ground. An exercise such as a side-stepping monster walk, was scored as having both bilateral and unilateral weightbearing.

8.	Eccentric Emphasis
o	The authors of the program being analyzed needed to explicitly state that the exercise was to be performed in a deceleratory fashion or other language that made it clear that the goal was to accentuate or focus on the eccentric portion of the exercise. Exercises with a commonly accepted clinical focus to be eccentric such as planks, lunges and step downs. The muscle group that was targeted with the eccentric intervention was also noted during analysis.
The 9 categories will be assessed individually as being present or not in the exercises.

registration_responses.q2: A scoping review of the exercises used in an ACL prevention program.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q15.question:
1.	Multiplanar
o	The exercise must include primary movement across two or more of the three cardinal planes. If an exercise was scored as multiplanar, then the two or three planes were also identified in the analysis.

2.	Sagittal Plane
o	The primary movement of the exercise occurred within the sagittal plane. Supine straight leg raise in supine is an example of isolated movement about the sagittal plane.

3.	Frontal Plane
o	The primary movement of the exercise occurred across the frontal plane. An example of an isolated exercise to the frontal plane would be a sidelying straight leg raise 

4.	Transverse Plane
o	The primary movement of the exercise occurred across the transverse plane. Exercises that are more difficult to categorize, such as the “clam” were put into transverse and frontal if the author reported it as utilizing two planes of motion. Seated external rotation is an isolated transverse plane exercise.

5.	Z-axis Rotation
o	The exercise needed to provide a force that would induce an internal rotation of the femur about the longitudinal z-axis of the body as illustrated in FIG. XX. The hip and knee must be in an extended position as if the body is in a weight bearing alignment. 
 
6.	Bilateral Weight Bearing
o	The primary movement of the exercise had both lower extremities contacting the ground in a long axis position where the hip was in a position of extension with the acetabulum over the femur in an upright bipedal position. Quadruped was not considered bilateral weight-bearing for this reason.

7.	Single Limb Stance
o	The exercise was performed on one lower extremity that was full weight bearing and contacting the ground. An exercise such as a side-stepping monster walk, was scored as having both bilateral and unilateral weightbearing.

8.	Eccentric Emphasis
o	The authors of the program being analyzed needed to explicitly state that the exercise was to be performed in a deceleratory fashion or other language that made it clear that the goal was to accentuate or focus on the eccentric portion of the exercise. Exercises with a commonly accepted clinical focus to be eccentric such as planks, lunges and step downs. The muscle group that was targeted with the eccentric intervention was also noted during analysis.
registration_responses.q17.question: The 9 categories will be assessed individually as being present or not in the exercises.

attributes.title: Acupuncture and manual therapy for rotator cuff tears: a protocol of for systematic review and meta analysis
attributes.description: The tears of rotator cuff is caused by the tears or aseptic inflammation of tendon tissue such as subscapular muscle, supraspinatus muscle, infraspinatus muscle, teres minor muscle, etc., which make up the rotator cuff. Managements of rotator cuff disease often include acupuncture and manual therapy, usually delivered together. The aim of this review is to assess the effectiveness and safety of such interventions in patients with pain and dysfunction caused by rotator cuff tears.

q1.value: Tang Hong Zhi, Luo Fei, Fan Huaying, Huang Li, Liao Shichuan, Yu Wenjing, Chen Yunbei, Qin Xuefei, Chen Jiao

q2.value: Rotator cuff tears is one of the common musculoskeletal complaints, and significantly impacts a person’s health-related quality of life. Epidemiological studies have reported that 20% of people over 20 years old suffer from rotator cuff tears, while 25% of people over 50 years old suffer from rotator cuff tears, which is the main cause of shoulder joint pain and dysfunction and greatly affects patients’ work efficiency and quality of life. An epidemiological study in the United States reports that 4.5 million people are hospitalized every year for Rotator cuff tears. The rotator cuff is composed of supraspinatus muscle, infraspinatus muscle, subscapularis muscle and teres minor muscle. It starts from the shoulder rib and attaches around the humeral head, forming a sleeve like structure at the anatomical neck of the humeral head. The function of the rotator cuff is to support and stabilize the shoulder and humeral joint, maintain the sealing function of the shoulder joint cavity, maintain the synovial fluid to nourish the articular cartilage, and prevent the secondary osteoarthritis. The treatment principle of rotator cuff tears is to reduce pain and improve the function of shoulder joint. The most common actions taken at present to relieve the symptoms of rotator cuff tears include steroid injections, oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physical therapy, exercise therapy, manual therapy, ultrasound therapy and acupuncture. In practice, people with rotator cuff tears seldom receive a single intervention in isolation. Acupuncture and manual therapy usually delivered together as components of a physical therapy intervention, are commonly used in the management of rotator cuff tears. Acupuncture is commonly used for musculoskeletal disorders, and it has been suggested as a meaningful nonsurgical intervention for managing shoulder pain and dysfunction. Manual therapy is also commonly used in the management of rotator cuff tears. Manual therapy includes any clinician-applied movement of the joints and other structures, for example mobilization (of which several types exist) or manipulation. The aims of both types of interventions are to improve function, promote healing, increase joint range, strengthen weakened muscles and correct imbalance in the stabilizing function of the rotator cuff. The mechanism of acupuncture treatment has not been fully elucidated. Some studies have pointed out that the mechanism of acupuncture and moxibustion treatment may be related to the local effect, which refers to the release of neuropeptide and other substances by stimulating the sensory nerve endings of skin and muscle tissue. The research shows that acupuncture can promote the release of β-endorphin and increase the concentration of 5-hydroxytryptamine in brain tissue, so as to reduce the sensitivity of tissue to pain and improve joint activity. Manual therapy can stimulate peripheral mechanoreceptors and inhibit nociceptors to reducing pain, and can enhance exchange between synovial ﬂuid and cartilage matrix to increasing joint mobility. Previous systematic reviews have not assessed acupuncture and manual therapy for rotator cuff tears together. Consequently, we decided to conduct a systematic review based on the best currently available evidence and methodology to evaluate whether acupuncture and manual therapy is effect and safety for pain and function of rotator cuff tears.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 1.Types of studies We will include randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of acupuncture treatment for pain and dysfunction caused by rotator cuff tears. RCTs in English and Chinese will be included in the review. RCTs using single-blind, double-blind or open-label design will be included. For crossover trials, data are extracted from the first period only, to avoid potential carryover effects. 2. Types of participants Adult patients (aged ≥ 18 years) diagnosed with Rotator cuff tears will be included, with the symptoms of shoulder joint pain or dysfunction enrollment in the research. We will exclude trials that include any participants with a history of signiﬁcant trauma or systemic inﬂammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, hemiplegic shoulders, or pain in the shoulder region as part of a complex myofascial neck/shoulder/arm pain condition. 3. Types of interventions All randomized controlled comparisons of acupuncture or manual therapy versus placebo, no treatment, another active intervention will be included. Trials evaluating the primary or add-on effects of acupuncture and manual therapy, acupuncture alone, and manual therapy alone are eligible. Acupuncture will be considered only of it involves needle insertion at acupuncture points, pain points, or trigger points, and had to be described as acupuncture. We will exclude other methods of stimulating acupuncture points without needle insertion (such as laser stimulation or transcutaneous electrical stimulation). Eligible manual therapy interventions include mobilization, manipulation and massage. We will exclude studies that only compare different forms or methods of acupuncture (e.g. transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation) and compare acupuncture with any complementary and alternative therapies for which the efﬁcacy is not yet established (e.g. Chinese herbs).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Two review authors (THZ and LF) will independently screen all abstracts identiﬁed from the literature search, then exclude those that are clearly irrelevant (e.g. studies focusing on other conditions, reviews, etc.). We will obtain full texts of all remaining references and the same two review authors will screen and exclude clearly irrelevant papers according to the selection criteria. We will resolve disagreements by discussion or with a third review author.
No response

1.Primary outcomes  Pain intensity (measured by validated scales, such as the visual analogue scale (VAS) or numeric rating scale);  Shoulder function (measured by validated scales, such as the Constant-Murley score (CMS), Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) total scale, Dutch Shoulder Disability Questionnaire (SDQ-NL), Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score, University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA) Shoulder rating scale, or the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) rating scale). 2.Secondary outcomes  Health-related quality of life measured on validated scales such as Short-Form 36 (SF-36) Health Survey or EuroQol;  Patient global assessment of treatment outcomes, such as the Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC);  Adverse events;  Active range of motion of shoulder joint;  Proportion of patients who finally ended up receiving shoulder surgery.
No response

We will use Rev Man software (Review Manager Version 5.3 for Windows, The Nordic Cochrane Centre, Copenhagen) to carry out statistical analysis. A random effects model will be used to calculate the pooled effect estimates, because substantial clinical heterogeneity is expected among the studies included in this review. If considerable heterogeneity (I2>75%) is observed, we will not meta-analyze the trials and will qualitatively synthesize the data.

q21.value: We will contact the authors in China via telephone, and authors from elsewhere via email to obtain missing data, if necessary. For all outcomes, we will carry out analyses, and both per-protocol (PP) analysis and intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis will be accepted. Attrition rates, for example dropouts, losses to follow up, and withdrawals, will be investigated. If the missing data is not accessible, we will exclude these articles and synthesis the rest of the included studies.

attributes.title: Evidence for specialist treatment of people with acquired brain injury in secure psychiatric services: systematic review and narrative synthesis
attributes.description: Objective: To systematically review evidence that can inform the arrangements for the specialist care of adults with ABI who may require secure psychiatric services.

summary.value:
This registration provides a link to the systematic review protocol for the systematic review entitled: "Evidence for specialist treatment of people with acquired brain injury in secure psychiatric services: systematic review and narrative synthesis".

Authors: Liz Shaw(1), Michael Nunns(1), Simon Briscoe(1), Amelia Mosley(2), Daniel Dalton(3,4), Rob Anderson(1), Jo Thompson Coon(1)

Author affiliations:
1. Exeter HS&DR Evidence Synthesis Centre, Institute of Health Research, University of
    Exeter Medical School, University of Exeter, Exeter, UK.
2. NHS England Specialised Commissioning Mental Health, Skipton House, 80 London Road, London,     
    SE1 6LH 
3. NHS England, Skipton House, 80 London Road, London, SE1 6LH
4. Norfolk & Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust, Trust Headquarters, Hellesdon Hospital, Drayton High 
    Road, Norwich, NR6 5BE

This work was undertaken as part of the National Institute of Health Research Health Service and Delivery Research (HS&DR) Programme (NIHR 130320), by the Exeter HS&DR Evidence Synthesis Centre.

This version (final) of the protocol was originally registered with Open Research Exeter on 6th January 2020.

attributes.title: GoodReports
attributes.description: Developing and testing the effectiveness of an online tool to help health researchers find and use reporting guidelines to improve the completeness of reporting
attributes.withdrawal_justification: need to add the institution affiliation

attributes.title: Empowerment versus Competence Based Gender Interventions: Meeting Intersectional Needs
attributes.description: Building on the results of the previous studies, we conduct an experiment focusing on whether a gender diversity intervention tailored to the racialized gender stereotypes of different ethnic groups of women engender success among participants. This will be a 3x3 quasi experiment, involving 3 ethnic groups of women (White, Asian, Black ) and 3 levels of women's initiatives (empowerment-focused, competence-focused, baseline). After being exposed to gender initiatives, participants will fill in scales related to intervention success (e.g., career engagement, perceived inclusion, perceived relevance and success) and the extent to which the intervention was congruent to stereotypes that participants experience. Participants will be recruited through online survey platforms.

summary.value: This pre-registration contains the following: the study design, power calculation information, collection procedure, a lit of materials and measures included in the study, expected hypotheses, and analysis plan. I have also included a figure showing the expected pattern of results.

registration_responses.summary: This pre-registration contains the following: the study design, power calculation information, collection procedure, a lit of materials and measures included in the study, expected hypotheses, and analysis plan. I have also included a figure showing the expected pattern of results.
